image.altText: Lyn Read is sitting, wearing an aqua green jumper. With her dog between her arms.

props.synopsis: It was a highly sophisticated yet common scam. One that cost Lyn Read $50,000. Money the terminal cancer patient was saving for her last days and to pay for her funeral.

title.children: Lyn Read lost $50,000 in a scam, money she needs to pay for her funeral

image.altText: A close up photo of a phone with dating apps like Tinder, Grindr and Bumble on the screen.

props.synopsis: Popular online dating platforms are being threatened with greater government regulation unless they lift their standards and improve safety for users.

title.children: Dating apps threatened with regulation unless they improve safety

image.altText: An open suitcase with a torch and bushfire guide inside; hands place will

props.synopsis: Most Australians are aware of the risk of natural disasters, not all of us actually prepare. But some are leading the way, having their suitcases packed with essentials, their properties cleared of fuel and learning how to fight fires.

title.children: 'Evacuate now': When Sarah got to the evacuation centre, she realised she'd forgotten to bring so much

image.altText: Voters at polling booths in Canberra in October 2016.

props.synopsis: It's the last day to register or change your details with the Electoral Commission if you want to vote in the Indigenous Voice to Parliament referendum.

title.children: Enrolment for the Voice referendum closes tonight. Here's what you need to know

image.altText: Chris Bowen in a navy suit and tie in  front of the australian flag at a press conference

props.synopsis: The federal government releases figures to try to shut down growing calls from the opposition to consider nuclear as part of Australia's future energy mix, with Energy Minister Chris Bowen saying there would be a "massive cost to pay".

title.children: Energy Minister says replacing coal-fired power stations with nuclear would cost $387 billion

image.altText: A man in a suit is interviewed for television.

props.synopsis: One of the taxpayers helped by ATO whistleblower Richard Boyle has spoken out for the first time, describing the prosecution of the person who gave him a lifeline as "insanity". Mr Boyle's wife has also spoken to 7.30 about the toll the six-year-long ordeal has taken on the couple.

title.children: Richard Boyle faces the prospect of four decades in jail. His wife says all he did was tell the truth

image.altText: Tameka Yallop (blurry in the foreground) carries her daughter as she waves to an applauding crowd at the FIFA Women's World Cup.

props.synopsis: The Matildas will move an Olympic qualifier to Perth Stadium to accommodate tens of thousands more fans trying to get tickets.

title.children: Matildas Olympic qualifier moved to bigger stadium to allow 40,000 more fans after 'soaring demand' for tickets

image.altText: Russell Brand is pictured singing with a microphone in his hand.

props.synopsis: On Saturday, Channel 4 aired an episode of Dispatches in which Russell Brand was accused of rape, sexual assault and abuse based on allegations from four women who knew him over a seven-year period.

title.children: Russell Brand has been accused of rape, sexual assault and abuse. Here's what we know

image.altText: A profile picture of UK comedian Russell Brand

props.synopsis: Britain's BBC says it is "urgently looking into the issues" raised by allegations of sexual assault made against the broadcaster's former employee, British comedian and actor Russell Brand, who denies the accusations.

title.children: BBC investigating after sexual assault allegations made against Russell Brand

image.altText: One man wears a cap and blue check shirt and jeans smiling, another in denim jacket and shoulder length hair, smiling

props.synopsis: One of Australia's biggest rock bands, Silverchair ended with a whimper, not a bang. And so too did their friendships … almost.

title.children: 'We should have gone out in a blaze of glory': What really tore Silverchair apart

image.altText: police vehicle being hauled on tow truck on regional road.

props.synopsis: Police are searching for a man carrying a firearm who fled from a property in northern Victoria when police approached him.

title.children: Armed man on the run, police car loses control and rolls near Shepparton

image.altText: A man wearing a suit and tie runs his hand over his hair while standing between two people

props.synopsis: Danushka Gunathilaka, 32, pleads not guilty to one count of sexual intercourse without consent after he went back to the woman's eastern Sydney home in November last year.

title.children: Sri Lankan cricketer choked woman and removed condom during sex, court told

image.altText: A lady standing in front of a hedge with her hands rested on a low brick wall, smiles towards the camera

props.synopsis: The Australian soap star will also be remembered as a best-selling author, poet, philanthropist and a businesswoman as fans, family and colleagues pay tributes on social media.

title.children: Neighbours actor Joy Chambers-Grundy dies aged 76

image.altText: Five men wearing PPE gear and face masks look on as they stand amongst rubble and debris

props.synopsis: People whose homes were swept away by flooding in Libya's eastern city of Derna a week ago are facing the dilemma of whether to stay and risk infection or flee through areas where landmines have been displaced by the torrents.

title.children: Libyan flood survivors weigh water shortages against landmine risk

image.altText: Eddie JOnes looks past a Wallabies player

props.synopsis: Wallabies coach Eddie Jones apologises for their loss to Fiji in the group stage at the Rugby World Cup, which has them in danger of not making the quarterfinals for the first time.

title.children: 'They should be throwing croissants at me': Eddie Jones takes full responsibility for Wallabies' historic loss

image.altText: Students in a classroom with male teacher in background.

props.synopsis: Poor mental health and excessive screen time are the biggest problems facing young people, according to a new survey of more than 2,000 Australian teachers. New resources will be made available for teachers in a hope to create more conversations on mental wellbeing.

title.children: 'Nervous rants' and crying at school: Teachers say poor mental health is the biggest issue facing Australia's youth

image.altText: Multiple neighbours characters look surprised

props.synopsis: Neighbours received an all-star send off in 2022 but now the beloved Australian soap is heading back to TV.

title.children: Neighbours returns to Australian screens tonight. Here's how to watch it and why it's back

image.altText: Business people walk past a shiny black sign that reads "Reserve Bank of Australia".

props.synopsis: The Australian share market is trading lower as investors wait for foreign central banks' next interest rates meetings, while Michele Bullock begins her first seven-year term as RBA governor. Follow live.

title.children: New dawn at the RBA as Michele Bullock begins as governor, ASX lower ahead of overseas interest rates meetings

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Apart from the US Federal Reserve and Bank of England meetings this week, the Bank of Japan's meeting is also a key focus for markets this week. Why? Because the Japanese central bank's governor has suggested that it could end its negative interest rate policy, with its 2% inflation target in sight — paving the way for possible interest rate hikes. Last weekend, governor Kazudo Ueda told the Yomiuri newspaper that the Bank of Japan could have enough data by the end of the year to determine whether it could end negative rates. "Once we're convinced Japan will see sustained rises in inflation accompanied by wage growth, there are various options we can take ," Ueda was quoted as saying. "If we judge that Japan can achieve its inflation target even after ending negative rates, we'll do so ." The BOJ currently guides short-term interest rates at -0.1% under its negative rate policy, and caps the 10-year government bond yield around zero as part of efforts to reflate the economy and sustainably achieve its target. With inflation exceeding its 2% target for more than a year, markets have been rife with speculation the BOJ will soon start raising interest rates. It's that speculation that markets are keenly looking out for with Friday's decision, and any signs that the BOJ might be moving away from its ultra-loose policy faster than previously thought.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bank of Japan's rate meeting will be a key focus for the end of the week

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you missed this last week, United Auto Workers are striking against Detroit's "Big Three" automakers after failing to reach a deal on new contracts. UAW members went on strike on Friday at General Motors, Ford and Stellantis, and is considered the most ambitious US industrial labour action in decades. It's the first time the UAW has gone on strike at all three automakers at the same time. Unions and representatives at the "Detroit Three" are set to resume talks, but there appears to be no immediate resolution on the horizon. Around 12,700 UAW workers are on strike as part of the coordinated labour action, which is targeting the three assembly plants after their previous four-year labour agreements ended at midnight last Thursday. General Motors, Ford and Stellantis make up around 40% of the US market. Along with higher wages, the UAW is demanding shorter work weeks, restoring defined benefit pensions, and stronger job security as automakers shift towards EVs. Should the strike widen to include all 146,000 UAW members at the three companies, it could be the largest automotive industry strike in 25 years — since more than 150,000 GM workers walked off the job for nearly two months in 1998. If that action widens, that would put "half a billion [US] dollars per day" at risk in the US economy, according to RSM's chief US economist Joe Brusuelas, and slow the country's economy considerably. "While that amount is large in nominal dollar terms, it would not be large enough to tip the economy into recession ," Mr Bruselas said last week. "In the end, the impact of a such a strike would be modest compared to previous generations."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: United Auto Workers strike rolls on for a third day

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Today's nerves on the markets are also partly due to investors waiting for the RBA to release the minutes of its latest cash rate decision to assess its interest rate outlook. The RBA will release the minutes from its September meeting at 11:30am AEST tomorrow, after it decided to leave interest rates on hold at 4.1% again at its September 5 meeting. So why are investors so eagerly waiting for this? Because they're looking for clues about future interest rate decisions and how the economy is tracking — especially with inflation still above the RBA's 2-3% target. The RBA's statement on its latest monetary policy decision noted that services inflation was a sticking point in the economy, as it is globally, and there were "significant" uncertainties around the outlook — adding to the central bank's statement that future rate rises may be needed to curb inflation. We'll bring you the highlights from those minutes in tomorrow's blog, but if you're wanting to refresh your memory with this month's decision, here's the story from Rachel Pupazzoni and I two weeks ago:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Coming up: The RBA's interest rate outlook

featuredLink.title: Hannah is one of thousands of home owners seeing the light as RBA leaves rates on hold again
